p: Samit Soni is an Assistant Professor of Information Technology Management at the College of Management at the Georgia Institute of Technology. He got his Masters and Doctorate degrees in Information Systems at the University of Texas at Dallas in August 1999. His research interests are in the area of the design of telecommunication networks and issues related to infrastructure design and the application of new technologies.

He has published in: Annals of Operations Research, Decision Sciences, European Journal of Operational Research, INFORMS Journal on Computing, Information Systems Frontiers, and Telecommunications Systems.

p: Sridhar Narasimhan is a Professor in the College of Management at Georgia Institute of Technology. Professor Narasimhan's research interests are in the areas of computer network design, distributed databases, IT Outsourcing, and E-Commerce. He is a member of ACM, IEEE, and INFORMS.

He has published in: Management Science, Journal of MIS, ORSA Journal on Computing, IEEE Transactions on Communications, IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man and Cybernetics, IIE Transactions, Computer Communications, Decision Sciences, Computers and Operations Research, Computer Networks and ISDN Systems, Annals of Operations Research, Naval Research Logistics, Group Decision and Negotiation, European Journal of Operational Research, Journal of Database Management, Information Technology & Management Journal, and Information and Management.

p: Larry J. LeBlanc is a Professor of Operations Management and Information Technology in the Owen Graduate School of Management at Vanderbilt University. He received a Ph.D. and Master of Science in Industrial Engineering/Management Science from Northwestern University, Evanston, Illinois in 1971 and 1973, respectively. He has been a Visiting Professor for periods of several days to four weeks at Linkoping Institute of Technology (Sweden), France Telecom, the University of Ulm (Germany), the Technion (Israel), the University of Chile, and INRO (the Netherlands).

His research interests include operations research models for routing and topological/capacity design of telecommunication and logistics networks. Other interests are international operations and manufacturing strategies, especially comparisons of U.S., European, and Japanese manufacturing practices and subcontractor relationships.

Previously, he received a Japanese Government Research Award for Foreign Specialists in 1994 for travel to Tokyo and living expenses for studying small and medium manufacturers. He served as a Scientific Advisor to France Telecom during 1996 and 1997. He has been the principal investigator for research contracts from the National Science Foundation and from the Research and Special Programs Administration and the Urban Mass Transportation Administration of the U.S. Department of Transportation. He has published more than 50 refereed journal articles and co-authored the book Introduction to Operations Research Models.

details.abstract: In this paper, we study the problem of the design of telecommunication access networks with reliability constraints. These networks form an important part of the telecommunications infrastructure of large organizations, such as banks. Using data patterned after an actual bank network in the U.S., we formulate an optimization model for this problem which specifically takes into account the various cost, and discount structures offered by telecommunication carriers. We then develop dedicated solution procedures for obtaining solutions. Starting from a cluster solution, we then use perturbation techniques which we developed specifically for this problem within an overall simulated annealing solution algorithm. We show how to make the solution procedure more efficient by implicitly determining the values for many variables. We then report the results of our computational testing for a variety of problems. We compare our solution to a lower bound obtained using a linear programming relaxation. We show that substantial cost savings can be realized with our model, and solution procedure. Finally, we discuss which types of annealing steps in the simulated annealing algorithm are important.
